Ms2ger: where does it say that?

annevk, http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/reviewer.js
tantek, HTML is a useful specification, HTML5 is the W3C's waste of time
Ms2ger - what's wrong with a feature frozen stabilization fork?
The HTMLWG
tantek: it's not maintained?
annevk - yes, that's certainly an issue until they empower new editors to take bug fixes from HTML.
you can only maintain a fork so long, because at some point features will come to depend on new features, or will be significantly rewritten, etc.
Ms2ger that sounds roughly like ad hominem - HTMLWG (or the people of)  being bad or not does not equate to HTML5 (or the details/ideas contained therein) being bad or not.
and maintaining a fork is a waste of resources I think
annevk - I doubt features will come to depend on new features, as that would likely break backward compat.
publishing a snapshot for lawyers, okay, but doing anything more is a waste of time
I expect most new features in HTML to be reasonably modularizable.
tantek: they do all the time actually
In many ways, HTML5 could be the CSS 2.1 of HTML.
tantek, you miss the point
tantek: e.g. when CORS was added existing features were defined in a different way
tantek, the HTMLWG is the reason the HTML5 spec is bad
Ms2ger - I'm willing to give the yet-to-be-named HTML5 editors a chance first.
annevk - "defined in a different way" != break backward compat
exactly
tantek, I'm not talking about hypothetical editors, I'm talking about trolls and the chairs
but you cannot easily take in fixes at that point
in practice I expect any new post-HTML5 features to be reasonably modularizable.
it's not clear that there's a need for further bloating a monolithic spec
or when we merge CORS and fetching
you cannot easily take such fixes in
I expect to see a bunch of module specs that extend HTML5.
going to be a mess
tantek, who is going to write those specs?
Ms2ger whoever wants the new features
annevk - perhaps merging CORS and rewriting fetching would be a good HTML5.1 update.
I suspect it's more likely that Hixie is going to write them
There aren't many competent editors around here
Anyway, I could be doing something useful
tantek: it's that kind of talk why I left the CSS WG; planning about drafts instead of working on tangible things
annevk - it's easy enough to ignore such threads/conversations if they don't interest you.
well yes, I quit the HTML WG
I have no hope they're going to be doing anything useful

dunno how to do that without breaking the Web Service end points
hsivonen: btw I'm wondering if maybe it's time to remove the HTML4 and XHTML1 presets from the validator UI
I think very few people are actually using those
MikeSmith: only on Validator.nu or also on the W3C validator?
both
MikeSmith: what about the legacy DTD stuff on the W3C validator?
I think Jukka is the only one who has ever commented on those, and the only reason he has was to complain that the HTML4 checker doesn't follow SGML rules
hsivonen: what about it? you mean the HTML4 facet of the W3C validator, or the 3.2 and older?
it does seem that it happens that people who think validator.nu (as opposed to html5.validator.nu) only does HTML5 validation accidentally end up doing HTML4 validation with the defaults
ah
MikeSmith: do you mean keeping DTD-based anything around in the W3C Validator?
hsivonen: no I don't want to keep anything DTD based around anywhere except in the legacy W3C validator
MikeSmith: but the legacy validator is staying around at the W3C?
yeah
b
but eventually the Nu Markup Validator is going to be at http://validator.w3.org/
I see
and the legacy validator will be moved to http://validator.w3.org/html4 or somewhere
but yeah, I'm not particularly enthusiastic about keeping the HTML4 schema around
hsivonen: so I think that along with removing the HTML4 and XHTML1 presets, if we did that, we should change the doctype checking so that it doesn't ever try to use those
basically, make the behavior like html5.validator.nu
MikeSmith: yeah
and maybe include a message to say that if you want to do HTML4 or XHTML1 message, use the existing W3C DTD-based validator
on the Web Service side, there's the issue that validator.nu now accepts custom schemas but html5.validator.nu doesn't
*HTML4 or XHTML1 checking
hsivonen: I see
MikeSmith: I don't really want to encourage anyone to use DTD-based validation
OK
I don't want to encourage people to use XHTML1 or HTML4 doctypes
hsivonen: redirect html5.validator.nu to validator.nu, only expose the complex stuff as a service, and be done with it?
annevk: the thing is that the complex stuff has worse perf characteristics
annevk: so it's not nice to put the custom schema-enabled Web Service and the common-case GUI on the same host
does it have noticeable impact?
how many API consumers are there?
though maybe that could be addressed by 1) discontinuing Schematron support or 2) moving the whole thing to Heroku and hoping that superior infrastructure takes care of the user-visible issues
annevk: occasionally, validator.nu gets DoS'ed
annevk: non-malicuously AFAICT
annevk: I don't have proper metrics
you could ask the consumers to move to a different API during some time period
(I should probably get some)
and then disable it
annevk: yeah, except I have no communication channel with them
hsivonen: sounds like you should set one up :)
moving the validator to Heroku would be technically sensible
but it scares me to host anything in the United States
hosting it in France is legally reckless enough
are you scared the host will turn over data of validator users?
annevk: no, I'm scared about DMCA compliance and crazy liabilities I don't even know about
annevk: as for the EUCD, Finland and France are in the same boat anyway
maybe switzerland
the most scary thing about France is their anti-Nazi laws
I don't intend to be a Nazi, but I don't know how crazy French enforcement is when it comes to echoing 3rd-party content (via Show Source or quotations in error messages)
I'm hoping it's clear enough that validator.nu doesn't really host any 3rd-party content it might echo
annevk: as for handing over use data, the good thing is that the validator isn't in the business of storing users' content

annevk: but it's still annoying that pretty much every competent hosting provider in Europe eventually wants to serve U.S. customers or have a data center in the U.S. to enable their European customers serve U.S. end users faster

so all your cloud data are belong to U.S. TLA agencies even if your provider is nominally European
I thought some of them offer options on only storing data in Europe
in particular for EU governments who do not want to store data in the US
this global internet, local laws thing sucks though
I think that's annoying
annevk: I doubt that helps much with staff to incarcerate in the U.S.
at least that's the general sentiment of the accidentally honest Microsoft rep
ooh
annevk: for [citation needed]: http://www.zdnet.com/blog/igeneration/microsoft-admits-patriot-act-can-access-eu-based-cloud-data/11225

hsivonen, FWIW, I believe Wikipedia stores all its data in the U.S. specifically because U.S. laws are most favorable to its interests.  The U.S. has very defendant-friendly defamation law, and strong free speech guarantees in general, relative to a typical European country.  German courts have ordered wikipedia.de taken down at least once, and there have been credible complaints of infringement of British copyright law, but in both cases Ame
rican law was clearly on Wikipedia's side.
America is a bad place to host U.S. classified documents, gambling sites, and maybe a couple other things (some types of pornography?), but overall it tends to be safer than most European countries.
I think the Netherlands is good too.
That's with respect to prosecution, though.  If you care about the government snooping on your data, the story might be different.
Although I suspect most of Europe is relatively cooperative with U.S. investigations.
AryehGregor: indeed, hosting in the U.S. makes sense for Wikipedia

AryehGregor: and if you start with the assumption that U.S. TLA agencies can get your non-public data anyway, then hosting non-public data in the U.S. makes sense, because at least you are defending against snooping by *other* governments
Right.

For a typical site provider, the U.S. seems to be among the most legally friendly places to host your site, because it has very strong free speech guarantees in practice relative to most other countries.
However much some people might complain.
AryehGregor: but that the U.S. makes sense for an org the size of Wikimedia Foundation doesn't mean it makes sense for someone smaller
Well, it's true that legal protections on paper aren't very useful if you can't afford to be sued.
AryehGregor: because even if you have the law on your side, legal stuff in the U.S. is expensive
Is it a lot cheaper other places?
AryehGregor: yes
How so?
AryehGregor: well, insurance companies would know, and it's easier&cheaper to get legal insurance for any territory except the U.S. and Canada
But realistically, you still strongly want to avoid a court case anyway, right?  You don't want to have to pay for insurance to start with, and insurance doesn't prevent countless hours of lost time.
(I think part of what makes some countries much better for lawsuit insurance is the loser-pays rule some countries have for civil cases.)
AryehGregor: that's a big deal
That doesn't really help a typical individual much, because they have to pay up-front in case they do lose, but if you're insured it probably makes a huge difference.
AryehGregor: another rule that makes civil cases saner is a ban on punitive damages
AryehGregor: i.e. a principle that the damages awarded to the plaintiff can never exceed the suffered harm

Punitive damages aren't usually a huge deal in American tort cases, I don't think.  I think unreasonably high pay-outs for intangible harm like emotional damage are more of a problem, at least from anecdotal observation.
(in if you want to punish the defendant more, make it a criminal case and pay the fines to the state)
AryehGregor: anyway, hosting in the U.S. makes a great deal of sense if you have a U.S.-based legal department anyway
Yes, that's certainly true.
AryehGregor: otherwise, not so much
The best way to minimize legal liability in any event is to be in as few countries as possible.
(aside: I've occasionally wondered how Google dares to have a data center in Finland--a country that doesn't have proper judicial review of search warrants.)
(maybe they count on the officers who could perform a search being sufficiently afraid of Google's ability to pursue after-the-fact remedies)
(if the police in the U.S. had the kind of search powers the Finnish police has on paper, there'd be no end to abuse of police power in the U.S.)
Fortunately, U.S. police search powers are very effectively curtailed by the exclusionary rule, since that means that it's generally pointless for them to perform illegal searches.

Stevef_, I think the discussions between you and various WHATWG participants are often characterized by substantive points made on both sides that are obscured by inflammatory language, which encourages each side to dismiss the other.  So for instance, in this discussion just now, both you and annevk referred to things the other one said as "nonsense".  I would comment on the actual blog post you linked to, but it's not loading for me.

Stevef_: All I am saying is that spreading the message that WHATWG does not care about accessibility is spreading a lie. If we did not care about it, there would be no discussion about it, longdesc would not have been removed, etc.
Stevef_: There is disagreement about what the right way forward is, but no disagreement about whether accessibility is a field worthy of attention

annevk: i don't believe I have said that WHATWG does not care about accessibility, what I have said is that in regards to accessibility API work, it is being done at the W3C and I or my fellow editors never got anythting positive on the work or interest shown in the work from the WHATWG side. In regards  to the other aspects in the example i cited I did a put a lot of effort testing ,...

...researching, speaking with users on the effects of  the accessibility of title attribute as implemented in the real world and based my arguments on that, with little or no interest in arguing the issue on its merits, the work was largely ignored or dismissed by the WHATWG. What I do belive is that accessibility issues get more consideration at the W3C, but that is something we disagree upon
Stevef_: I think Hixie's main point about html-api-map is that it can use some cleanup
Stevef_: e.g. HTML in its section WAI-ARIA already defines the default roles
Stevef_: so that information should not be normative in html-api-map because it's redundant
Stevef_: but how e.g. "link role" maps to system APIs is new information and should be normative
Stevef_: that's probably why Hixie largely dismissed the document

Stevef_, I haven't followed these discussions closely, but I really think the mutual attitude of dismissiveness comes more from the way the discussion is phrased than its substantive content.  The WHATWG people don't understand or agree with some of the things you're saying, this makes you get frustrated because you feel you can't make them listen to you, you lash out, they get annoyed at you and stop listening.  I don't think the problem is
that anyone doesn't care about your work; it's some combination of a) you aren't phrasing it in a way that makes sense to them, and b) they have different assumptions or priorities.

annevk: its a work in progress and if anybody bothered to look at it lately its got a lot better, none of the formation is normative currently, the ARIA stuff is there for informative purposes, some of the ARIA mappings are differnet from what is currently in HTML as they are implemnted differently

MikeSmith:  (and hsivonen)  I'd agree with losing the doctype based schemas in the v.nu interfaces (at least the web facing ones, local installations might be different)  although "<MikeSmith> I don't want to encourage people to use XHTML1 or HTML4 doctypes " I'd agree so it's unfortunate that the bug asking to have  a doctype for xhtml+xml that wasn't one of those (and works) just got...
...wontfixed :(

david_carlisle: if there are doctypes that work and aren't in the spec, please reopen the bug listing them. I said in the bug already that if there are cases that already work it's a no-brainer to add them. It's the ones that don't already work that I wontfixed.
Personally, I use the HTML4 Transitional option mostly when I want to suppress the deprecation warnings/errors.
Yuhong: why would you want to use deprecated stuff?
To validate other pages, not my own.
why do you validate other pages?
For fun, mostly, but sometimes there are reasons to do so.
What is wrong with validating other pages?
Hixie it is good to see that the autocomplete stuff has seen some iteration to better match hCard.
There's actually been a lot of prior art/research on the subject here: http://microformats.org/wiki/hcard-input
(nothing conclusive, but the research may be useful to help inform decisions for the autocomplete stuff)

(aside: the suggestion to use schema instead of vCard had to either be a joke/troll, or naïvete - surprised they didn't also try using Google Base, Google Data, FOAF, or if you really want to go back, MS Passport contact schemas for that matter)

tantek: On modularization, remember XHTML 1.1
tantek: On modularization, remember XHTML 1.1?
Yuhong - yes, I was in the HTML working group at the time and very much remember the problems.
Hence why I'm suggesting the CSS model of modularization rather than the XHTML model.
XHTML modularization was both a) a disaster, and b) nearly useless
Which reminds me that if I was there in 2004, I would suggest proposing a new version of XHTML that IS backward compatible with XHTML1.
Before resorting to starting the WHATWG.
Yuhong - see my blog posts about it from that era, e.g. http://tantek.com/log/2003/01.html#L20030114t1345
I was pushing for backward compatible work on XHTML1/HTML4 back in 2003 - *in* the HTML Working Group itself. Unfortunately I was the only one advocating this focus (in the WG).
so yes, I've witnessed firsthand both a modularization failure (XHTML) and a modularization success (CSS2.1/3)
And unfortunately what got submitted by Mozilla/Opera was not that.
thus given that data, I'm advocating CSS-style modularization, where we agree to modularize on top of a monolithic spec, rather than to replace it.
Back in 2004, of course.
thus as we have CSS 2.1, we now have HTML5
and we have CSS3 modules that build on top of CSS2.1, we can have HTML modules that build on top of HTML5.
Sorry, did not realize the difference between CSS and XHTML.
modularization.
there's more than one way to modularize
Agreed.
so it's easy enough to pick one that is mostly working, and improve on it, rather than the one that was a nearly a completely failure
Of course.
Yuhong - you'll notice that WHATWG does tend to leave CSS stuff to the W3C CSS WG - because it tends to do a good enough practical job that it's not worth reinventing.
it's not perfect, but no standards org/community is.

making to REC is hardly a measure of success :-)
2 is valid though

perhaps I should have said "for process-type" rather than "for spec-types" for 1.
annevk - also, I consider overall CSS modularization a success especially when *some* modules fail.
the biggest problem with CSS is the vagueness of the specs
that means that we successfully isolated features that the market was not as interested in, and stopped them from holding back features that the market wanted
but that's more or less inevitable for the modules because they all rely on a foundation that is too vague
Hixie - s/CSS/specs in general
no, not any more
euhm, features that the market wanted? you mean like a better layout model?
I mean sure, some tiny stuff was successful, such as color
tantek: XHR, HTML, Origin, CORS, lots of the new APIs -- lots of new specs these days are written very tightly and not vaguely

tantek: but it hasn't kept improving, and is now no longer close to cutting edge in terms of precision
and as I said, CSS modularization is not perfect at all - it's just shown a degree of success (in contrast to other modularization attempts which have shown nearly total faliure)
it's aroudn the same level of precision as SVG specs, which is to say, way better than the status quo around 2000, but not at the level we expect in 2010

even though we know how to write better specs, I would offer that lack of spec precision isn't stopping implementers of the CSS modules
so yes, the specs *can* be better written, however, they are doing a 'good enough' job to help the platform move forward
could we do an even better job? of course. do we have enough editors to do so? no. so we settle for incremental improvements.
